reviewText: I can't help but compare this to another boxed set by the same distributor calledHorror Classics 50 Movie Pack Collection, which I watched before this one. The movies in the Horror set span from the silent era through the 60s and includes some genuine classics (Nosferatu, Night of the Living Dead, Metropolis), some infamous flops (The Beast of Yucca Flatts), and everything in between. It runs the range from monster movies to sci-fi to murder mysteries. The present Sci-Fi collection is not as noteworthy. There is not a single film here that I would consider a classic, but there are a few that are infamous for their badness (Eegah! and Santa Claus vs the Martians). This collection focuses on the 50s and 60s with a few from the 70s and even one flick from the early 80s. The later films all appear to be made for TV. While the Horror collection runs the range from extremely good to extremely bad, the Sci-Fi collection is more uniformly mediocre. Therefore I am giving it only 4 stars instead of the 5 I gave the other set. However if you like old b-movies (especially sci-fi, horror, and sword & sandal) then you will get much enjoyment from this inexpensive collection.The buyer should be aware of the shortcomings of this boxed set (which are the same as in the Horror set). The DVDs are all 2-sided with 2 or 3 movies per side. There are zero special features or adjustable subtitles. All discs come in cheap cardboard sleeves which must be forced into the plastic box. The movies themselves are all public domain with terrible audio and video quality. None of the film has been cleaned up at all. There are anomalies throughout, and often the picture is dark and difficult to make out. I do not consider this to be a problem because it is to be expected from cheap collections of public domain schlock, but you should be aware in case you are an HD-obsessed cinephile.It appears that there are multiple versions of this collection, and it has been said that earlier versions contain the classic film Robot Monster. I own the newest version of this collection, the one with the hard case that features Gammera the giant Japanese turtle being attacked by the military on the cover. This new version does NOT include Robot Monster. If you want Robot Monster, here it is:Robot Monster. Be aware that Amazon's prices of Robot Monster change considerably over brief periods of time. I bought my copy on Wal-Mart's website for cheaper than Amazon usually has it.I've only watched a handful of the movies here, but I'll hit some of the highlights for you:MOON OF THE WOLF: A 1972 made for TV movie in which a sheriff must solve local murders and the killer turns out to be a werewolf. Extremely cheaply made, but that works in this film's favor. The minimalist filmmaking approach actually makes this movie more suspenseful than many modern movies.VOYAGE TO THE PREHISTORIC PLANET:  A charming but forgettable high-adventure lost world movie about a ship that crash lands on Venus and has to avoid being eaten by dinosaurs. Movies like this are a dime a dozen, but this one works in spite of an over-reliance on stock footage. I have not yet seen the sequel, Voyage to the Planet of Prehistoric Woman, also in this collection.TEENAGERS FROM OUTER SPACE: 50s drive-in schlock. Terrible special effects (pretty much nonexistent - the giant lobsters are formed using hand shadows) and lousy acting somehow make for a rather entertaining and even mildly suspenseful alien invasion teen drama.ROCKY JONES, SPACE RANGER: There are two movies here from the 50s TV series Rocky Jones. BORING BORING BORING. This can only be described as an extremely boring knockoff of Flash Gordon that put me to sleep very quickly.HERCULES AGAINST THE MOONMEN: There are 5 or 6 Hercules movies in this collection. This is the only one I have watched so far. The plot is incredibly stupid and characters belong in Saturday morning cartoons, but this action packed sword & sandal epic is actually pretty entertaining.KILLERS FROM SPACE: A military test pilot is thought killed in a crash but was really abducted by aliens. I didn't finish this one, but it looks interesting.THE SNOW CREATURE: Badly made and predictable but somehow highly enjoyable abominable snowman / missing link movie. Decent adventure flick.FIRST SPACESHIP ON VENUS: An American movie made from the remains of a Japense film that somehow works. This is a highly enjoyable and exciting flick for anyone who likes movies about space travel and exploring other planets.BLOOD TIDE: A true enigma. In 1982 after his career was revived playing in Star Wars and Conan the Barbarian, JAMES EARL JONES somehow got stuck with this horrendous made-for-TV movie. This movie is badly made in every possible way but somehow manages to be VERY VERY GOOD. The story doesn't make any sense, but the bikini-clad women running around Mediterranean scenery combined with James Earl Jones' bad attitude make up for this movie's many many shortcomings.DESTROY ALL PLANETS: There are several movies here about the giant Japanese turtle monster Gamera who is sometimes a hero and sometimes a villain. This is the only one I have watched. Destroy All Planets is an incredibly cheesy but heartfelt and highly enjoyable movie in which Gamera helps two boys in a submarine fight invading aliens. This is a great example of how a movie that is so incredibly bad can be so incredibly good.EEGAH! Infamous as Mystery Science Theater 3000 fodder, Eegah! has no redeeming values whatsoever except that it is great for making fun of.
summary: Good but not as outstanding as 50 Horror Classics
Title: N/A

reviewText: Very campy and B movie quality. Useless flashing lights, odd campy close fitting uniforms with a tight fitting cap, and it is out of sync or a dubbed, possibly french movie. I didn't care enough to look it up on IMDB or anything. Hard to believe this came out the same year as Star Wars, but Star Wars did set a new standard so I will not use it against this film. Dialogue is really bad: "Captain two bright points of light approaching!" and "It might be two asteroids" as a goofy projection of two ships up real close is in the view-screen. Just as a couple of examples. Opening credits of a star field looks like a disco mirror ball projection.I don't really go for camp but here are some good points here. There is a mind to mind interface, (for making love), with cheesy moaning running concurrent as they are laying on their "space couches", and Captain Hero seducing the Fem lead without it telling her she lost herself due to the influence to machines. In that scene she has the most awful haircut. Looks like a space mullet without her skin tight space cap on, lol. And a ship AI. But they made the AI have a booming dramatic over top grandiosity.So if you like camp more than I you might check it out. Streamed on Prime. It is very campy. I actually laughed a time or two and I watched it all so not a one star.

reviewText: Al Bradley is genius.. Yes, I believe this is one of the 20th centuries great unknown gems! How can a movie with such unbridled atmosphere and feeling fly under the radar for so long?? None the less, this is special and all of you out there who just don't get it, don't worry, you probably never will.. for these of us who do, check out War of the robots and Star Odyssey!! The later being an instant classic/masterpiece!! It's akin to an epic trilogy!! LMK if U get it.. rixmat@gmail.comThx.
summary: One of the best underated sci fi movies. Ever!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, read the list of titles carefully.  This compilation, with a few exceptions, really scrapes the bottom of the barrel.  Even for those of us who enjoy the occasional home matinee populated by aliens with zippers down their backs and earthly heroes wearing plastic fishbowls on their heads may find that many of these films are just too cheesy to be tolerable.Annoyingly, the compilers have done--so far as I can tell--absolutely no clean up on either the visuals or the sound.  As a result, some of the films are scratched, dirty, and difficult to understand.All in all, a disappointing collection.  Dirt cheap, though.  Caveat emptor.
summary: Poor selection and trashy production values

reviewText: My dad had seen about 2/3 of these movies when he was a kid, which amazes me, since they're not rememberable movies.  A good collection of the "B" Movie collection.  Lots of these movies are cheesey, campy and fun to make fun of.  I'm a MST3K fan, so I love these old movies too.  Although, I haven't seen the uncut version of "Manos: The Hands of Fate" yet...but who would really want to?!

reviewText: SCI-FI CLASSICS COLLECTION is an eclectic mix of hokey science fiction and fantasy, with a sprinkling of action films (of the sandals and swords variety). One commonality here is the typically low score all fifty of these "classics" got from users of a film-related website. On a one to ten scale, the current average for this set calculates out to: 3.2.Scoring is relevant only to plot, editing, effects, etc, and doesn't consider stock condition or audio/video transfer quality. This multi-pack may only be for the most ardent of sci-fi/fantasy fans, as well as lovers of well-aged cheese.The following program list includes individual ratings, main actors, years of release and country of origin (if other than USA)--(2.7) The Amazing Transparent Man (1960) - reviewText: I bought about a fourth of these movies individually before I knew of this package;  they were very economically priced, however even with duplicates this pack would be worth purchasing. Many of them are Roger Corman classics. Others are so bad that you have to watch then to tell people that you too have eclectic tastes. The individual titles come and go so get them all while you can.Be sure to read all the individual reviews (after you buy the collection).A few of highlights:The Incredible Petrified World - 66 minutes longQueen of the Amazons - original title "Amazons and Gladiators"Robot Monster - terminator in a fur suitShe Gods of Shark Reef - natives and sharks but no She GodsThe Amazing Transparent Man - you can see through this oneThe Wasp Woman - a stinging performanceSanta Claus Conquers The Martians - it is an abduction storyTeenagers From Outer Space - so what is new?Crash of the Moons (Rocky Jones) - female ruler with a nasty attitudeMesa of Lost Women - Horrible background musicKillers From Space - saw this as a kid - still spooky - Ping-Pong ball eyesZontar," The Thing from Venus" - rubber VenusiansThere are a few glaring omissions including "The Crawling Eye"

reviewText: Yes, these are low-budget cheese-rs AND they are older than your Grandpa's slippers..but at around 10 bucks each, how the hell can you go wrong with 50 movies!Notwithstanding that there are no "special features" or commentary, but so what? Most of the people who made or starred in these movies are probably dead already anyways.Low-priced and bulk-quantity, retro Sci-Fi fans will have a blast with this huge collection.

reviewText: Where can you get so much pleasure for such a small investment? Sure, many of these oldies are "corny"... perhaps that's what I enjoy about them. Surely, you'll find at least a few that you'll really enjoy and that makes this well worth the price. What better way to spend a dark rainy night! I have a number of these 50 and 100 packs of science fiction, horror, and other entertaining dvd collections. This collection has several of my personal favorites.
Title: N/A

reviewText: OK, make no mistake, this is a collection of 50 public domain sci-fi (plus some Hercules and jungle epics tossed in) movies. It's a mixed sack of goo to be sure, but is still the best bargain out there by light years! Consider that most, if not all of these movies can be found in other collections ranging in price from 10-20 times as much! MESA OF LOST WOMEN for instance can be purchased seperately for around $7. Here, it costs about .50! This is quite a difference, doncha think?? The quality varies, but who cares? These versions are no worse than their ultra-expensive counterparts! Public domain flicks are not known for their great condition, they are simply movies that any company can get a hold of and package any way they see fit. Why pay a fortune for movies that are only worth pennies anyway?? Buy this now! Also, grab the 50 CLASSIC HORROR MOVIES collection as well, before it vanishes!...
Title: N/A

reviewText: No CGI here. When I saw the image Amazon had up for the title, I thought it looked like it was made in the 50's or 60's, and was maybe Russian or Japanese. After watching the movie, I was able to find out more about it, and indeed, it includes footage from Russian movies, and in fact was made in the 1960's (though Amazon says 2005).The movie itself is seriously washed out of color, and appears black and white in most cases. It's a shame, I think with vibrant colors it would be a whole different film. The models of the spaceships, especially at the beginning, are great. I loved it. Cool "60's style ships. And the hover car is a hoot to see today, though I am sure it was pretty cool when the film was made.  There is even a (very) large robot in the film.The women are pretty enough, but their role is not as large as you would think. And as I mentioned, the washed colors and poor copy of the film leaves a lot to be desired.So, if you like old scifi movies, despite any lack of a real story, this would be a good film to watch at least once. I gave it two stars because I just thought the models and effects were well done. To be honest, I might come back later and check this film out again.
summary: Cool model space ships in this one

reviewText: SciFi Classics is a collection of 50 movies that have only one thing in common: they are all public domain and as such it is possible for them to be presented in highly affordable collections. I paid $21.99 for my set and that comes down to about 44 cents per movie. The way that movie tickets cost nowadays, you really cannot complain about this collection.Anyways, here is how I rate the movies in SciFi Classics:Good:The Amazing Transparent ManAssignment: Outer SpaceHercules and the Tyrants of BabylonHercules UnchainedKillers From SpaceLaser MissionLost JunglePhantom From SpaceThe Phantom PlanetPlanet OutlawsQueen of the AmazonsThe Wasp WomanZontar, the Thing From VenusAverage:Colossus and the Amazon QueenFirst Spaceship On VenusHorrors of Spider IslandRobot MonsterShe Gods of Shark ReefThey Came From Beyond SpaceVoyage to the Prehistoric PlanetVoyage to the Planet of Prehistoric WomenWarning From SpaceWhite PongoBad:The Astral FactorAttack of the MonstersThe Atomic BrainBattle of the WorldsBlood TideThe Brain MachineBride of the GorillaCosmos: War of the PlanetsCrash of the MoonsDestroy All PlanetsDevil of the Desert vs. the Son of HerculesEegahThe Galaxy InvaderGammera, the InvincibleHercules Against The MoonmenHercules and the Captive WomenThe Incredible Petrified WorldKing of Kong IslandMenace From Outer SpaceMesa of Lost WomenPrehistoric WomenSanta Claus Conquers The MartiansThe Snow CreatureSon of HerculesTeenagers From Outer SpaceUnknown WorldThe Wild Women of WongoAll in all, an incredible bargain.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a big fan of old cheesy sci-fi movies. And despite the fact that this set as a few unbearable and ultimately boring films to watch, this set is worth buying if you like this sort of thing.I have not watched every movie on this set, but I found "The Phantom Planet," "Robot Monster," "Phantom From Space," "Killers From Space," and "Gammera the Invincible" to be pretty entertaining. So anyone of those is a good place to start in my opinion. I also watched "The Wild Women of Wongo," and it is probably the most ridiculous movie I've ever seen. But it's hilarious. DANCE FOR THE DRAGON GOD!!!There are some quite boring movies on this set. "Battle of the Worlds" is Claude Rains' worst mistake ever (he was the only good thing about the movie). "Voyage to the Prehistoric Planet" is probably Basil Rathbone's worst mistake. It's ulimately mind-numbing and boring. So save those for a later day when you're up late and can't sleep. You'll pass right out.The picture and sound aren't always the best (however, this is the only way you can watch many of these titles). But for the amount of movies you're getting at the cost this set is selling for, I recommend this purchase if you like cheesy sci-fi.
summary: For the price you're paying, you can't go wrong

reviewText: The movies on the Sci-Fi Classics set are:Disc 1, Side A - The Incredible Petrified World, Queen of the Amazons, Moon of the WolfDisc 1, Side B - She Gods of Shark Reef, The Amazing Transparent Man, The Atomic BrainDisc 2, Side A - Horros of Spider Island, The Wasp Women,Disc 2, Side B - Voyage to the Prehistoric Planet, Voyage to the Planet of the Prehistoric WomenDisc 3, Side A - Kong Island, Bride of the Gorilla,Disc 3, Side B - Attack of the Monsters, Gamera the InvincibleDisc 4, Side A - Santa Claus Conquers the Martians, Teenagers from Outer SpaceDisc 4, Side B - Rocky Jones, Space Ranger: Crash of the Moons, Rocky Jones, Space Ranger: Menace From Outer SpaceDisc 5, Side A - Hercules Against the Moon Men, Hercules and the Captive WomenDisc 5, Side B - Hercules and the Tyrants of Babylon, Hercules UncahinedDisc 6, Side A - The Lost Jungle, Mesa of Lost Women,Disc 6, Side B - Assignment: Outer Space, Laser MissionDisc 7, Side A - Killers From Space, Phantom From SpaceDisc 7, Side B - White Pongo, The Snow CreatureDisc 8, Side A - Son of Hercules: The Land of Darkness, Giants of RomeDisc 8, Side B - First Spaceship of Venus, The Alpha IncidentDisc 9, Side A - The Astral Factor, The Galaxy InvaderDisc 9, Side B - Snowbeast, Unknown WorldDisc 10, Side A - Blood Tide, The Brain MachineDisc 10, Side B - The Wild Women of Wongo, Prehistoric WomenDisc 11, Side A - They Came From Beyond Space, Warning From SpaceDisc 11, Side B - The Phantom Planet, Planet OutlawsDisc 12, Side A - Colossus and the Amazon Queen, Eegah,Disc 12, Side B - Cosmos: War of the Planets, Destroy All Planets.The first movie I watched on this set was the cheesy 1959 Teenagers from Outer Space because I had seen about twenty minutes of it late at night before and I was curious at how the silly movie ended. There are four fun Hercules movies; well I guess there are five if you count the Son of Hercules: The Land of Darkness. I have to mention one of the worst movies every put to film is on here, Santa Claus Conquers the Martians.Disclaimer - I received a free review copy from Tower PR  in exchange for an honest review.

reviewText: I've made it through about 30 of the movies to this point and have found the majority of them to be entertaining and actually quite good.  Yes, some of them are slightly corny and the special effects are as low budget as humanly possible , but they are enjoyable viewing.  Some are hard to watch without laughing at, but you can only do so much with really bad acting and boring dialogue.  Still, there are some real gems in here. Especially when you spot well known actors in the very early stages of their careers.

reviewText: Have a slow Saturday afternoon?  Pop in one of these DVD's and go back to your childhood.  This is a great collection (for a great price)of old movies that you would probably never see on TV.  Some are better than others, and some are not worth much, but all-in-all, I find watching these to be relaxing and fun.  And isn't that what it's all about anyway?
Title: N/A

reviewText: OK,it's not nearly as good as the Horror fifty pack but to an old crap hound like myself it's as good as finding a wallet full of money and no I.D. Forget some of the negative reviews here they're obviously from cheesaholic neophytes who don't know their Jess Francos from their Roger Cormans but if you want to see some rock bottom laff riots like THE ATOMIC BRAIN,ROBOT MONSTER,SANTA CLAUS CONQUERS THE MARTIANS and THE GALAXY INVADER then dig right in. As is the case with the other 50 packs the quality varies and some of the titles are come ons but some of the gripes have been that about ten of these tales are actually sword and sandal Hercules movies. Uh,is this a bad thing? Oiled up men wrestling rubber monsters for the hand of some gorgeous Italian babe makes me very happy indeed but I guess some folks expect every film to be STAR WARS for their twenty bucks.If nothing else this set is worth it for it's inclusion of all of the original Gamera films( Yay, he's a giant flying fire breathing turtle who loves children) and the prints are just as good as the ones on Alpha for six bucks a piece.So take A VOYAGE TO THE PLANET OF PREHISTORIC WOMEN and meet THE PHANTOM FROM SPACE. We'll go on a LASER MISSION and when it's all over we can meet up with THE WILD WOMEN OF WONGO  with the rest of the die hard trash movie fanatics.As the Blues Brothers would say "What do you want for nothing...Rubber Biscuit?"
summary: Rubber Biscuit and jumbo cheese tray

reviewText: If you were hunting for great films like "The Day The Earth Stood Still", "War of the worlds", "Them"............. This is definitely NOT the set for you. These films are for those who enjoy shows like "Mystery Science Theater", "Elvira", or "USA'S UP ALL NIGHT." Also these films are great for videos in need of public domain footage, that does not require an hour to download.Yes, I recommend this set to people interested in those things listed above. Of course I think I would save the money on this package and instead buy the largest package of films (Horror 250 Movie Pack) to save a few bucks and have alot more entertainment. I got mine for less than $50.00, and am very happy with this purchase.
summary: Great Public Domain footage that does not require an hour to download.

Title: N/A

reviewText: With all of the existing science fiction movies available for the viewer to look at, it was amazing that perhaps the worst 50 movies of all time were picked for this compilation.  Public Domain is one thing but the worst movies that could be picked were indeed picked.  This collection made no sense and followed no pattern.  The quality of the movies chosen were poor at best and the old saying of "you get what you pay for" certainly rings true here.  In the future, I hope that whoever develops these collections of movies takes into consideration that the viewer does indeed has a brain --- and a desire to view some movies that fall into a science fiction category.

reviewText: It's nice that they decided to recycle old 1950's sci fi props. It's nice of them to pay homage to all those non Hollywoood films that think plots are for losers. It's nice of them to write it like a play with a whole lot of unnecessary dialogue. It's nice of them to ignore science of any type. It's really nice of them to have given some bad actors a chance. It's nice of them to let junior high kids write the story line. It's nice the fooled someone into giving them 2 stars.  Yeah.. these guys are just too damn nice to be making movies.

reviewText: I know this looks like a great deal, but most of these "classics" were losers from the start, playing second or third bill at the drive-ins.  There are a few good ones like some of the old Hercules series, but many are throw-aways.  Also, the video and audio quality are not good.  I think it's better to spend a few extra bucks and build a good library of real sci-fi classics like War of the Worlds, It Came From Outer Space, The Day the Earth Stood Still, The Thing, etc.  All these are available at Amazon, most under $15.Another thing, at least one was so poorly processed it wouldn't play on my DVD player.  And no matter how cheap, what good are they if the quality is awful?  I actually felt kind of foolish showing these to my wife and friends.

reviewerName: Hardyboys.us "The Hardy Boys Unoffical Home Page"
reviewText: The SciFi Classics Collection is misleading - many of the films included are sword & sandal epics, jungle movies, adventure or outright horror films. The quality of the prints used ranges from abysmal to satisfactory. Some of the films are so bad as to be unwatchable. Don't get me wrong, I love grade Z scifi but many of the films are not in the least enjoyable on any level. The two "Prehistoric Planet" films (both of which use the same film as a basis) are terrible. Please note that the advertised "Robot Monster" is NOT included in this set. All-in-all, not worth the price of admission.

reviewText: ok first thing first, if you want top of the line transfers and great movies out of a collection that sells 50 movies for less than $25.00,then DON"T BUY THIS SET,BECAUSE THIS SET WILL DISAPOINT YOU!!!!!now if your into seeing some great b thru z grade sci-fi films then this is for you!! the collection has some good,some bad, and some that ,well i don't know what you would call them. that said the movies are a lot of fun and for the most part all are family friendly,which is a nice bonus. no gore here or bad words just silly sci-fi fun if your in that kind of mood.not for all taste but my family likes them and my sons watch some of the movies with me and that is why it gets 5 stars from me. relax and enjoy.

reviewText: Half of these movies are in black & white. I used to be the person that hated B&W's but once I saw greats as Teenagers from Outer Space, Lost Jungle and Mesa of Lost Women, my mind was changed. Between this and the Sci-fi Invasion pack, the Invasion pack is more of 70's-80's Sci-fi, this one is more of 50's-60's. The average who even likes movies in general will give this pack an above average rating, I've seen about 30 movies so far and have really enjoyed it. Out of the 30 movies I've watched out of 50, I have watching 12 movies more than once. You will have a lot of fun with this pack, trust me.
summary: as of now, It doesn't get any better than this

reviewText: If you like mostly older movies that are good for getting friends together and mocking, (with love), this is a very good starter kit. Some of these were actually used on MST3K. Many of the movies are not great transfers, many are in black and white, but all were released for entertainment at one time. Some include famous actors before they became famous, some include actors just there to draw a paycheck. Many have good performances and amazing special effects, considering the low budgets. Anyway, a good reference to have before these movies disappear completely. I don't believe anyone will be remastering any of these for Blue-ray.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay, if anyone out there has any nostalgic memories of watching old, low-budget flicks on some hoaky local station's "Chiller Theater" or just want to see some of the films that gave the guys on Mystery Science Theater 3000 plenty of comic material, then this set is for you. This isn't the good stuff as classic sci-fi goes; this is public domain, the "how-not-to-make-a-movie" stuff, even a low-budget one.Most sci-fi fans will be disappointed to find that some of these films are of a genre unrelated to sci-fi; some will make you gringe. I'm not going to go into a lengthy breakdown, but one clear case in point is Mesa of Lost Women; this laxative will have have you wanting to run. The movie is supposed to be a horror, but the real horror is the acting and music (which is part burnt-out mariachi, part "lady who plays piano for all the school plays"). The music will not let up on your nerves. One plus to this set is that it's the perfect cure for mild insomnia and why I affectionately refer to it as "cheese". Like cheese it... ages well, some of it really stinks, but too much will put you on lockdown.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: Brandon Lee, Ernest Borgnine and Debi Monahan should have made this movie watchable.  About the only thing I found interesting in this movie was the exposure that Debi Monahan got in her dress.  The rest of the movie is a loosely connected series of action scenes that have almost nothing to do with a laser.  I was quite sad about not having a laser.Michael Gold (Lee) is a super spy out to rescue Dr. Braun (Borgnine).  There is a lot of action and hitting and shooting and jumping, and the next thing you know there is this girl, Alissa (Monahan), who we all think is Dr. Braun's daughter.  Alissa seems to be quite handy with guns and explosives for someone who supposedly works in a zoo.The next thing you know, we are in a desert and there is a big showdown and Gold gets shot in the back, and there are all kinds of blood on the front of his shirt, and yet Gold seems awfully spry.  There is still no laser at this point, but there is a big diamond (really big) that could be part of a laser if Dr. Braun is allowed to do his scientific laser thing.In order to stay within the spirit of the movie, there is more shooting and blowing up, and it takes three attempts to take out the #1 bad guy.  Then there is a needless scene with a stolen helicopter and the movie is finally over.  There is STILL no laser.  I was so disappointed.  We have a movie called "Laser Mission" and there was never a laser.I like a good action movie; it is just that this movie was not a good action movie.  I have to believe that the actors in this movie wish they could take this one back.  I know I would like to get back the time I wasted on this movie.  The only people who should consider getting this movie are those who have to have every Brandon Lee movie, or every appearance of Ernest Borgnine (which is past 200 television and movie appearances).  Everyone else should stay away; far away; really far away.Good luck!
summary: We Don't Need No Laser Mission

reviewText: With all the movies in their catalogue one has to wonder why Mill Creek couldn't have compiled a better sci-fi collection than this. Several titles do not make the grade as 'sci-fi', especially the Italian sword and sandal Hercules fantasies. Looking at the 'Nightmare Worlds' collection the opportunity existed to put together a pretty good set of genuine sci-fi flicks ranging from the silent era up to the 1960s when things began to change. Early "so bad it's good" B-grade sci-fi can be loads of fun. Unfortunately, a lot of what is here is just plain bad. At this price still worth having, but could have been much better.

reviewText: Where else can you get fifty sci-fi movies for less than seventeen bucks? For value alone this set gets four stars. The movies themselves have largely been reviewed elsewhere and vary widely in quality from the pretty good to the sublimely awful.It took me a few months (seven, to be precise) to make it through all fifty of these, and while none were life changing; some were good entertainment or (more commonly) good for a laugh.Some of my favorites include:"Santa Claus Conquers the Martians": one of the silliest concepts in history. Don't miss Pia Zadora in her role as "Girmar" (an acronym for "Girl Martian," by the way) and the most annoying theme song in film history by future "Gong Show" bandleader Milton Delugg."The Incredible Petrified World": this one starts the set off right with John Carradine in one of his gassiest roles ever."She Gods of Shark Reef": this movie is so amazingly inept that you will have to see it to believe it."Cosmos: War of the Planets": not a good movie at all, but features some of the worst special effects and most un-scary monsters in recent cinema history. (Beware of the talking jukebox.)"First Spaceship on Venus": made behind the Iron Curtain during the cold war; watch this movie and you will have no doubts why communism fell in the Soviet Union."Horrors of Spider Island": this one features the worst plane crash scene on film, and also the worst human to spider transmogrification scene of all time.But my absolute favorite of all these films is without question..."Zontar, The Thing From Venus," a movie so overacted, yet sincere that it begs repeat viewing. Between incredibly bad dialogue about things like the "plutonium-ruby crystal beam gun," silly incidental music, and a Venusian made of latex, twigs, and tissue paper, this one cannot be beat.The movies come four to a disc, and are each broken into four chapters, so it is difficult to access individual scenes, but for the price, this is some priceless sci-fi cheese.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been slowly making my way through these films, none of which I would ever want to watch a second time.  They are old, usually obscure, and most often truly terrible prints.  Virtually all of it is stuff that is a runner-up to the already second rate:  instead of Godzilla, you get Gamra.  Instead of Flash Gordon, you get Rocky Jones.  Etc.  There are also some utterly ridiculous ones, like Santa Claus conquers the Martians.  And then there are plenty of really really bad ones that have nothing whatsoever about them that a viewer would want to see.  Overall, these are not b-movies but c-movies.That being said, I saw a lot of these when I was growing up in the 1960s, when you took "what was on" or went and did something else.  Indeed, I would estimate that I saw 75% of these films, and at the time I absolutely loved them.  THey provided ideas for games we played with plastic soldiers, had good clear heroes, and plenty of campy humor.  THe good guys were handsome, the bad guys were ugly, the girls were shapely and often blond, the kids were intrepid and clean cut (this being pre-hippy era).  As such, I have experienced a flood of memories when I watch some of these films, though even at the time Gamera was too much for me.This nostalgia is wonderful and part of life, so I have enjoyed this collection a great deal.  Unfortunately, the films are rarely anything that I can share with my kids:  they are used to the internet and dvd's with far better special effects as well as, admittedly, far more sophisticated plot lines.  We do laugh at them, but they are not bonding experiences, just another thing that proves to them that dad is weird as they enter adolescence.I would recommend this for nostalgia value and as a very cheap addition to a film library.  Most of these films are so bad that you would never want to buy better prints of them anyway. There are occasional surprises, such as Journey to Venus, which I saw with my dad and always remembered:  it is an East German production (!) about an extremely dark threat that an international team sets out to explore, with many strange details thrown in; just that one film, which I truly loved and always remembered, makes this worth the price.
summary: should have been titled "Scifi junk classics"

reviewText: An enjoyable movie that is laugh out loud funny, without meaning to be. The movie has it's heavy-handed social commentary about the overwhelming need to be young and beautiful and also the cautionary theme of unbounded science. Typical 50's cinema.The video quality leaves quite a bit to be desired, but adds an air of authenticity to the b-movie mystique. A must for any 50's era b-movie aficionado.

reviewText: There must be a few different versions of this sci fi set. I purchased it mostly for the movie "Robot Monster" which some reviews said was in this box set. It however is missing as are "Battle Of The Worlds" and "Zontar". So don't neccesarily expect to get the exact same 50 movies listed or reviewed. You'll get most of them though. In my set, just three movies are switched with three other films. The films in this box set are mostly sci fi cheese! Some like "She Gods Of Shark Reef" and "Santa Claus Conquers the Martians" are so stupid that they are just stupid. Others like "Killers From Space" or the Gamera flicks are so stupid that they're hilarious! Most are pretty dull and tacky, but still fun to watch. It's hard to complain about getting 50 movies for so cheap, but I do wish this set had more focus. There are movies from the 1930's all the way to the early 1990's! Overall, a decent set of films and worth the price I paid.

reviewText: Bearing in mind that the 50 MOVIE PACK line is what it is, no-frills packages of public-domain films, I have to say that SCI FI CLASSICS is not up to the level of MYSTERY CLASSICS and HORROR CLASSICS, which I also own.  I've watched everything in the MYSTERY and HORROR sets, and, while the latter is padded with flicks that properly belong in the former, I didn't feel cheated by either.  Moreover, some of the films included, such as DETOUR, IMPACT, BLUEBEARD, and TOO LATE FOR TEARS, actually are classics of a sort, deserving of repeated viewings.Only about 36 of the 50 films included in SCI FI CLASSICS remotely qualify as science fiction or even as "sci fi" -- and the only "classics" among them are famous (or infamous) anti-masterpieces on the order of ROBOT MONSTER, TEENAGERS FROM OUTER SPACE, MESA OF LOST WOMEN, and SANTA CLAUS CONQUERS THE MARTIANS; the balance comprises sword-and-sandal strongman epics, e.g., HERCULES AND THE TYRANT OF BABYLON, and jungle epics, e.g., WHITE PONGO, QUEEN OF THE AMAZONS, and Clyde Beatty's LOST JUNGLE.  If you simply must have copies of low-budget programmers such as UNKNOWN WORLD, HORRORS OF SPIDER ISLAND, and THE INCREDIBLE PETRIFIED WORLD on hand for those occasions when THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL doesn't ring your chimes, you'll like this package.  Otherwise, beware.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Because this is a public domain set, the print and audio quality of these grade-B or grade-Z films isn't the best but they are still watchable.  In addition, there are some truly legendary films here for cult movie fans of the likes of Roger Corman (The Wasp Woman), and for those who love truly terrible movies including legendary cinema stinkers Eegah, Mesa of Lost Women, Teenagers from Outer Space, Bride of the Gorilla, and the incomparable Santa Claus Conquers the Martians.  Since many of these titles, which include some sword-and-sandal epics from the 1950s-1960s, are not available elsewhere, this is an indispensable set to have.  The price cannot be beat.  Recommended.

reviewText: What did they do -- pick the worst movies ever made and decide to put them all in one collection?  That is what it should be called -- "The Lamest Movies In the Science Fiction Genre."  I have never wasted as much time and money as I have in bothering to buy this set.  Almost every movie is not even watchable, it is so bad.  And, it is not bad in a good or funny way, even.  No close-captioning or decent sound quality, either.  Why bother?The only movies in this whole set worth watching:"Moon of the Wolf" -- early 70s with David Janssen.  At least this has a decent story-line and is entertaining."Gammera" -- one of the Gammera movies has an OK story and can be even somewhat entertaining."Hercules Against the Moon Men" -- definitely a "C" movie if there is such a thing, but still at least had a story.Most of the "films" in this set seem to have some type of pseudo-documentary at the beginning that bores a watcher in the first 5 minutes.  Almost all have an incomprehensible or no plot at all and no screenplay that anyone wants to listen to.Worst movie ever made = "Voyage to the Prehistoric Planet" with Basil Rathbone.  Basil must have been really hard-up for roles to have had anything to do with this turkey.  Either that, or they gave him a lot of money.This "collection" is mostly garbage and unwatchable.  Don't waste your time or money.  Not even worth 1/2 of a star.  Not sure why some other reviewers think these films have any quality to them.
summary: Total Waste of Time and Money -- horrible

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: If you are watching this film without the assistance of MST-3000, you are going to have to know where to laugh on your own. The film opens up with Gary (Alexander D'Arcy) conducting dancing auditions for a group of actresses of German extract. One dances ballet, another simply doffs her dress, while others show off their legs up sexy upskirts.The group goes Travels to Singapore, but alas they crash before they get there. Sadly, it is the type of crash where no one gets hurt and the women don'e have to eat each other. They arrive at an island with uranium ore and a huge spider. They find the cabin of "the professor" who is dead in a giant very fake looking spider's web. There is no sign of any decay.Gary gets bitten by a giant spider which instantly alters his DNA and turns him into a horrible spider-man, who stalks the girls. The girls like to skinny dip, which we see from a distance, take showers with their back to the camera, use whips on each other, and cat fight with sexy up skirts. The film uses a jazz soundtrack to make the girls more sexy. This is an early attempt to combine horror with sexuality...although they both lacked.This film is shot "Ed Wood" style with day and night scenes happening at the same time. (Who will notice?)  Also known as "Body in the Web." This ranks in the bottom 100 of bad campy films.No f-bombs, sex, continuity, or nudity as we know it. I rate it 5 stars for all the wrong reasons.

reviewText: Don't expect high quality video transfers or classic movies and you may enjoy this collection.  With 50 movies you'll most likely find a few you might really like here among some so-so features and some downright duds.  But at this low price you can't really complain.  I had several of these films on VHS so it's nice to now have them on DVD without paying a higher price to get them.  (Note: as others have noted the picture will look better on computer monitors and smaller TV's but not on the newer large screen 1080P TV's.)  So get your popcorn ready, pop in one of the DVD's and sit back and enjoy the show ...(or cringe at how bad some movies can be!)
summary: Not really classics but mostly entertaining
